From my experience with Mr. Garfield I would recommend that he have a greater opportunity to understand the components of the Teaching Framework AND their implications for teaching and learning.  Unfortunately the onsite coach who has been assigned to support him has provided support in planning, instruction and environment.  However, on the three occasions that she was to view ( with administration) to provide informal feedback to support his professional growth, he called out.  Additionally he has been provided the opportunity to visit classrooms to view various components of Literacy instruction (Centers, Guided Reading ), however he has been unable to demonstrate that he is able to implement what he is learning within his own classroom.    Teaching Fellows need to have greater exposure to the reality of being in a school in addition to the theory behind what occurs.
column21: It would be better if they had better experiential knowledge and understanding  of the responsibilities of a Teacher.  The reality of teaching is much more involved than many people may think it is.

column20: Thank you so much for your training and preparation of incoming teachers. Mr. Chase is a pleasure to have on staff, his passion for educating our youngsters is evident and his energy is a welcomed addition to our school.

column20: All first year teachers need support. As I tell all new teachers, if they follow the recommendations from administration, mentors and fellow teachers their practice will improve.
column21: the resources that I wish I had was more time to help fellows improve their practice. I would want to send them to more PD both in and out side of our school.

column20: Anna has already formed a wonderful bond with our other two ESL teachers. She has already assisted with NYSITELL administration. She is getting to know our ENL students and has especially formed a bond with our Entering and Emerging students.

We have only had Ms. Collins for two weeks.  The first week we worked with her to plan her class, so this is the first true week of instruction.  We will know more about her performance in the coming weeks but she has been diligent and resourceful so far.

column20: A very competent mentor has been assigned to the teacher, she is not making the progress we would expect. She is not learning and is not accountable.  The mentor has spent several full days in the classroom with her modeling lessons, rearranging the room, making charts, and demonstrating how to work with small groups. However, there is very little evidence of progress.
column21: More frequent visits from the NYC Teaching Fellows would provide more support.

column20: We encountered some difficulty in staffing this person in Galaxy and were going to move her from a permanent hire to provisional.  When faced with this challenge, she responded very unprofessionally.      Her response was:  Ms. Logozzo,    As per our conversation this morning you have withdrawn my nomination for one of several reasons:  Budget  My license  The position was provisional  Etc, etc    What I don't understand is why you sent me an email after hours and then ignored my several attempts at reaching you. I then reached out to my team leader who assured me that this was a mistake and that you would never do something like that. Well it seems you would. You could have had the common courtesy of telling me yesterday before I left, and save me the trip this morning only let me know that the email was in fact valid and that I was being let go.     It seems that this will be for the best because I would not want to work for someone who misrepresented themselves.     You knew from our interview that my strengths are the Humanities and that my weaknesses are Math and Science - to which you replied "What's important is building relationships". I think it would behoove you to follow your own advise.     To which I replied:  Ms. Awad,    The email you received was auto-generated by DOE HR.  I was offline last night, so I did not see it until this morning, along with your email.      I would have discussed this fact, along with the change from permanent hire to provisional hire with you this morning, had you not been so abrupt and quick to say, "this is for the best."     Your email below is insulting.  The DOE is a small world, I advise you not to burn bridges so early in your career.        Best,     Nancy Logozzo

Ms. Beccia has been an asset to our school since she joined us.  She is a voracious learner and has demonstrated her ability to decipher problems and quickly find solutions.  She has given her time freely to ensure that structures are in place to benefit our school.  She is a professional at all times and has a warm demeanor with children.  We are very happy to have found her.
column21: Not sure of this response.  I would prefer to ask the Teaching Fellow her opinion on what resources she might need.

column20: Ms. Ramos is eager to learn which is an area of strengthen.  During her internship with the Fellows she only worked in a Middle School.  As a result, she is struggling delivering instruction to Elementary school  students and classroom management.
column21: Ms. Ramos has extensive support provided by the school.  She has a school based mentor, 1:1 coaching support, weekly PD, outside PD, teacher team planning and peer coaching in classroom management and subject specific instructional support.      My feedback to the NYC Teaching Fellows is to provide the teachers with experiences in different grade levels and provide additional support in classroom management.

column20: This person put in or a medical leave after 9 days of teaching for a pre-existing condition. This person left a special education position leaving children without a teacher.
